Project loading failed: (r)etry, (q)uit, (l)ast, or (i)gnore?

I just tested it on a computer I haven't done any zipkin work on and it goes fine.  Perhaps there are some network problems preventing your build from grabbing it's dependencies?  Can you try to wget this:

http://maven.twttr.com/com/twitter/sbt-thrift2_2.9.1_0.11.2/0.0.1/sbt-thrift2-0.0.1.jar
Would you happen to be building this in China?
wget is ok , but where to put this file ?
Are you in China?  The build depends on being able to download certain artifacts from Twitter.  Your best bet is to set up a VPN to bypass the Chinese firewall and then re-try your build.

Sure, I am in China. but I guess it is not a VPN problem.

I rebuild  through VPN , but problem still.

and let's focus on the log  below:

[warn] [FAILED ] com.twitter#sbt-thrift2;0.0.1!sbt-thrift2.jar: Downloaded file size doesn't match expected Content Length for http://maven.twttr.com/com/twitter/sbt-thrift2_2.9.1_0.11.2/0.0.1/sbt-thrift2-0.0.1.jar. Please retry. (52886ms)

Downloaded file size doesn't match expected Content Length 
^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^

by the way,  http://maven.twttr.com/com/twitter/sbt-thrift2_2.9.1_0.11.2/0.0.1/sbt-thrift2-0.0.1.jar  can access without VPN
I don't believe anyone has used Zipkin on Windows before, so unfortunately you're on your own in figuring out how to get it working.

I just noticed that this would break in a vhost scenario where your root_url was something like http://www.example.com/zipkin/
I doubt anybody would do that if they're running zipkin in a cluster anyways, and if they're not in a cluster than finatra dominates the http port.
+1 I assume the build failed due to that test being flaky?
Yeah, it passed on the initial branch commit.
+1 from me, but Franklin is probably a better reviewer for this one

Can you comment on how relevant the existing centos guide is?
Should we delete it or is it still useful?

You can delete it. There are a few inconsistencies and could be updated but
the ubuntu guide should cover centos install as well..

Aaron

On Tue, Mar 12, 2013 at 5:16 PM, Brian Degenhardt
notifications@github.comwrote:

> Can you comment on how relevant the existing centos guide is?
> Should we delete it or is it still useful?
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/twitter/zipkin/pull/234#issuecomment-14803944
> .
Thanks for the docs.  Committed with a bit of editing.  One thing to note is that the default configs don't use zookeeper, so your zookeeper config may or may not be set up correctly.
I'll let Franklin review this one, but to my untrained frontend eyes it looks good.

I've never seen that before.  What OS is this on?

versus the scala+jvm you're running with.

+1, but would be good to give a more in-depth description for why the change is necessary, and how it fixes what's broken

If you bind to your primary public IP, then you can't get to the service on localhost.  Vice-versa if you're bound to localhost.  I kept getting confused when running ssh port-forwarding or some combination of development/production instances about which ip the service was listening to.  This also comes into effect when your ip changes, say I take my laptop home running zipkin and get assigned a new IP.  Binding to 0.0.0.0 makes the service reachable by both 127.0.0.1 and the public IP.  Most network services do it this way and rely on firewalls etc to limit access.
This build is going to fail because it depends on an unreleased version of finagle.  They should release finagle real soon now in which case this will start working.

Why not just use the web-based tools?

This is quite the beast of a branch. Generally it would be easier to review if it was split into a few different pull requests. Seems there's a couple of things happening: removing hadoop component, upgrading sbt, upgrading dependencies and cleaning up the deprecation notices. Do they all have to be done in one go?
I can't remember, what was the reason for removing the Hadoop module?

A lot of these things cascade into the others.  Hadoop didn't work as it
was, and it won't even compile on the new libs.  Scrooge won't compile on
sbt11, finagle5 won't play well with sbt12 scrooge.  So now we've upgraded
all the libs, upgraded sbt, deleted hadoop.

The deprecation warnings were the previous commit, just because I wanted to
merge this big change into a clean build.  If you want to see the diff
without them just go one rev back.

Finagle 6.4 now has scala 2.10 artifacts, so this should be working now.

The reason dapper has divisible sample rates is because endpoints participating in the same trace can have independent sample rates, so dapper needs them to line up occasionally.  Zipkin preserves the sample rate down the line, thus allowing us to have a much more varied rate.

Typically people just clone the repo and run it.  What are the artifacts you're referring to?  You shouldn't really care which version of scala zipkin is running against, because it's a standalone service.

If you're referring to the client library for Tracing, try taking a look-see at finagle-zipkin, which is built against 2.10.

I'd like to use some parts of zipkin to get them to run with brave (https://github.com/kristofa/brave-zipkin-spancollector. ).

Thus just running zipkin would not be enough.

The implementation uses:
- zipkin-common
- zipkin-scrooge
  for which I didn't find an artifact compatible with Scala 2.10. 

I tried checking out the project and changing the Scala Version in the build.sbt to generate the aritifacts locally. But the Scala Version seems to be defined/overridden somewhere else. Also checked the build properties found in the project directory but no trace of a version definition except for the one in the build.sbt .

We haven't built/tested artifacts on scala 2.10
There's a lot of dependencies on artifacts that we rely on that are not
available for 2.10.  You're welcome to give it a shot, but the short answer
for the question of whether we have them is "no"

I'm not sure why you'd need it though.  Surely brave can work with the
standard 2.9.2 version of zipkin.

So the set of spans with the same id is one monoid, (identity is the span without annotations), the set of traces with the same id is another monoid (identity is the trace without any spans)?
As an outsider already interested in using Zipkin, I'd just like to say that this looks like an awesome feature!

Yeah, it can logically be viewed that way, but the implementation is a bit different because there's no way of having span ids influence the scala type.

I created a special zero span that invokes identity when added to any span, and the plus operation just throws an assertion if the spans do not have matching id's.

Mostly this is useful for some scalding jobs I'm working on, but I think a second phase of this will be to go back and simplify some of the span aggregation code in the collector.
